lambda.definition: Curvature of the mode-augmented deviation connection ∇M \= δ \+ M.
theorem\_links: Main curvature operator entering all λ-decomposition terms.
Generates curvature from both geometric and modal contributions.

lambda\_curv.definition: Curvature of the base deviation connection ∇0 \= δ.
theorem\_links: Corresponds to the pure geometric part λ\_curv in the theorem.
Appears as the λ-term remaining when M \= 0.

lambda\_mode.definition: Curvature generated by δ acting on M and commutators of δ with M.
theorem\_links: Matches λ\_mode term in the canonical λ decomposition.
All modal curvature is produced solely by the mode field M.

lambda\_cross.definition: Curvature created by self-interaction of the mode field M (ψ×ψ, ψ×Φ, δ×ψ...).
theorem\_links: Matches λ\_cross term in the canonical λ decomposition.

lambda\_adjoint.definition: Dual curvature mapping producing divergence-like or codifferential curvature.
theorem\_links: Adjoint operator needed for λ-flows, λ-conservation, and λ-integrability checks.
Provides dual structure underpinning modal flatness conditions.

lambda\_to\_delta.definition: Maps curvature into deviation, encoding curvature–deviation bridge.
theorem\_links: Corresponds to λ→δ in the theorem’s expansion δλ \= λδ \+ λ→δ.
If M ≠ 0: λ→δ \= λᶜᵘʳᵛ \+ λᵐᵒᵈᵉ \+ λˣ.
